With strong domestic trade routes, Trump can expand his cities without relying on good relations with foreign powers. Combined with America's policy flexibility, Trump has plenty of options for how to pursue victory. Late game unique units and the Film Studio make America a cultural and military power house.
Xi Jinping
General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China

The son of a veteran of the Communist revolution, Xi Jinping slowly worked his way up the ranks of power, serving in a series of positions including governor and vice president before reaching the apex of his career. As president of the People's Republic of China, Xi has worked to fight the corruption that bogs down China's institutions and has sought to implement policies to strengthen China and realize the "Chinese Dream". He has also cracked down on dissent and consolidated power to himself, all the while increasing the belligerence of China towards its neighbors as he attempts to increase China's influence abroad.
Xi Jinping is a builder who can quickly construct districts and improvements with his powerful workers.

With workers that have extra charges and an ability to add production towards district construction, Xi can specialize in developing his land quickly. Paired with China's ability to earn larger inspirations and eurekas, Xi has the capacity to achieve a lead in both technology and civics.
Vladimir Putin
President of Russia

A former officer of the KGB, the Soviet Union's notorious secret police, Putin served in the Yeltsin administration following the dissolution of the USSR. When Yeltsin resigned in 1999, Putin assumed the position of acting president and began a reign that continues to this day. Strong economic growth and successful reforms increased his popularity, allowing him to win several elections, although most of these victories were tainted by allegations of voter fraud and harassment of opposition parties. When term-limited by the Russian Constitution, he had his right-hand man run in his stead, although it was widely assumed he pulled the strings behind the curtain. Following this interlude, he returned to the presidency in his own right in 2012. Since then he has adopted a more aggressive posture for Russia, invading and annexing Crimea after his puppet in Ukraine was deposed by pro-western forces and also intervening in Syria to prop up his ally, the dictator Bashar al-Assad, in the ongoing civil War there. It remains to be seen whether this is the extent of Putin's ambitions, or if he plans to rule Russia to his dying day and attempt to restore it to imperial greatness.
Vladimir Putin's Russia is positioned to be a strong expansive civilization.

With Russia's bonus to claiming tiles and Putin's bonus to attacking city states, Putin is capable of quickly building an empire. Spy bonuses allow Putin to get an edge over his rivals in the later game.
Narendra Modi
Prime Minister of India

Born to a family of grocers, Narendra Modi started on the political path at a young age, when at 8 years old he joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist organization. After college and studying at various Hindu temples, Modi went to work for the RSS, writing texts and serving as a regional organizer. Later, Modi was assigned by the RSS to help get their favored candidates for the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) elected, a task he proved skillful at. In reward for his efforts, the BJP appointed him Chief Minister for the state of Gujarat. His early term as Chief Minister was marred by the 2002 Gujarat riots, anti-Muslim violence that resulted in numerous deaths and significant property damage and displacement. Modi was criticized for his handling of the riots, but the BJP refused his resignation and he won the subsequent election for his party. In his later terms as Chief Minister, Modi focused on economic growth for Gujarat, managing to make the state the most busiiness friendly in India and one with an above-average rate of growth. Modi would use his success in Gujarat as a key selling point when the BJP entrusted him with party leadership going into the 2014 elections.

Modi led the BJP to victory in the 2014 elections, becoming Prime Minister in the process. The election was seen by many as a political realignment for India towards more right-wing politics. During the early part of his tenure, Modi implemented a plan of deregulation and tax reform and saw India become the world's fastest growing economy. His later monetary reforms proved less successful, with the demonetization of the ₹500 and ₹1000 notes being especially unpopular. Modi has also refocused government efforts away from welfare and education and towards infrastructure and sanitation. On the foreign policy front, Modi has followed the policy of his predecessors, strenthening the Indian military and seeking better relations and trade deals with other nations.
Narendra Modi is well positioned to build tall civilizations.

Modi's India has many cooperative bonuses that allow him to grow his cities larger than others. Combined with India's religious bonuses mean that India will be a civilization with large, diverse cities that can power Modi to almost any victory condition.
Shinzō Abe
Prime Minister of Japan

Coming from a long line of politicians on both sides of his family, including a maternal grandfather who served in the Tojo administration of Imperial Japan, it is not surprising that Shinzo Abe followed in the family trade. Educated in both Japan and America, Abe worked briefly for Kobe Steel before entering government service. Abe transitioned from the bureaucracy to the legislature following his father's death and slowly rose through the leadership positions of his party, the long-reigning Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). He eventually attained the position of Prime Minister, the youngest in Japanese history, but resigned shortly thereafter due to health reasons. A few years later his party, following a long decline in popularity, lost power for only the second time in its history. Abe returned to a leadership position in politics and staged a comeback for his party, returning it to power and himself to the Prime Minister's position in 2012. As a generally conservative politician interested in financial reform and increasing nationalism, Abe has provided stable if occasionally controversial leadership. Whether he will succeed in his vision of strengthening Japan, with its population aging and declining while its neighbors grow stronger, remains the great test of his future.
Shinzō Abe has a builder focus that allow him to lead a strongly science focused civilization.

Abe's Japan can quickly build science, commercial, and production districts with the bonuses for building compact cities that compound this advantage. Having a wildcard slot replacing a military slot gives Abe greater flexibility when organizing his government. Japan under Abe is especially good at science victories.
Angela Merkel
Chancellor of Germany

Growing up in East Germany, Angela Merkel earned a degree in Physical Chemistry and worked as a research scientist for several years. Following the fall of communism in East Germany, Merkel entered politics and won a position in the Bundestag after German reunification, a seat she still holds. Working her way up the ladder of the Christian Democratic Union party, she was eventually elected its leader following the resignation of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Leading her party to victory in 2005, Merkel became the first woman to serve as Chancellor of Germany. Her tenure has been fairly successful, providing a stabilizing force for Germany and Europe as financial crises have rocked the continent. She has had an energetic foreign policy, attending more international conferences than any other major world leader and leading trade delegations to many nations around the world. One of her passions has been to bring Europe closer together, a task that has become ever more difficult in light of Brexit, economically struggling member nations, and the ongoing migrant crisis. While her administration has not been without scandal, she has managed to weather many storms and seems poised to govern Germany for many years more.
Angela Merkel's Germany is well positioned to be a production and diplomatic powerhouse.

An extra diplomatic policy slot gives Merkel an edge with city states and the potential to better leverage the world Congress. Combined with Germany's production bonuses, Germany under Angela Merkel is well positioned to pursue Science, Domination, and Diplomatic victories.
Theresa May
Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

The daughter of a Church of England cleric, Theresa May earned a degree in geography from Oxford and spent the early part of her career in finance, among other institutions working for the Bank of England. May began her political career in 1986, at age 30, when she served as a councillor on the London Borough of Merton. She stood for parliament unsuccessfully in a couple constituencies before finally being elected to represent Maidenhead in 1997. From 1999 she served several positions in various Conservative shadow cabinets, and when the Conservatives were returned to power in 2010 she was appointed Home Secretary. She served in that position until David Cameron resigned in 2016, following the vote to leave the European Union (Brexit), when she ran for and won the office of Prime Minister, becoming the second woman to hold that position in UK history. With high ratings in opinion polls Theresa May called a snap election in 2017, but the campaign did not go well and her party lost seats, forcing her to form a coalition government with the Democratic Unionist Party in order to maintain power. The issue of negotiating Brexit still dominates her tenure, and it remainst to be seen if she can provide the "Strong and Stable" leadership promised.
Theresa May brings espionage and trade benefits to the UK.

Spies under May are automatically given the Seduction promotion, making them ideal counterspies from the start. This will make it easier for the UK to defend itself from foreign spies, an all-around useful bonus that especially pairs well with the British Museum ability, allowing Britain to keep all of those artifacts safe. May's bonus to trade means it is in her interest to maintain good relations with potential trading partners.
Emmanuel Macron
President of France

The son of a physician and professor, Emmanuel Macron earned degrees in philosophy and public affairs before joining the French civil service. After some time in the civil service, including work for the Ministry of Economy, Macron left to work in the private sector as an investment banker for Rothschild and Cie Banque. After four years as an investment banker, Macron rejoined the government in 2012 as a senior member of François Hollande's staff. In 2014 he was elevated to Minister of Economy and Finance, where his more business friendly approach caused him to clas with his fellow Socialists, eventually leading him to leave the party in 2015. In 2016 he resigned his government position and founded his own political party, "En Marche!" (meaning "Forward" in English). Under this banner he ran for President in 2017, an unusual election that saw the established parties fall to upstarts. Facing a runoff against Marine Le Pen of the far-right National Front, Macron recieved the endorsement of all the established parties and easily triumphed. His victory was later confirmed when his infant party won a stunning victory in the ensuing National Assembly elections, giving him full control of the legislature. At age 39, he is the youngest President in the history of France, and he is bringing his youthful energy to reform many aspects of the French government and economy.
Emmanuel Macron enjoys bonuses to many of the final stage buildings, allowing France under him to finish as strong as it starts.

France is naturally a very culture focused civilization, but most of its bonuses come in the middle of the game. With Macron, France gets additional bonuses that give it a general boost in the late game, allowing it to build on its earlier successes and finish the game in a strong position.
Michel Temer
President of Brazil

The son of Lebanese immigrants, Michel Temer earned a law degree and worked as a professor for nearly twenty years before entering politics and being elected to the Chamber of Deputies in 1987. During his political career he served on the committee that drafted Brazil's current constitution and also rose to become the leader of the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), one of the largest parties in the nation. In 2010 his party entered into coalition with the Worker's Party (PT), winning the election with PT member Dilma Rousseff elected president and Temer as her Vice President. When Rousseff was impeached for corruption and then convicted, removed from office, and jailed, Temer acceded to the Presidency. Temer has been embroiled in scandal himself, with two failed attempts made to impeach him.
Michel Temer can squeeze extra gold out of Brazil's natural resources.

Michel Temer makes Brazil even stronger in the rainforests, providing extra gold to all rainforest tiles. His gold bonus to oil wells means it is in Brazil's interest to begin exploiting this resource as soon as possible.
Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud
King of Saudi Arabia

The 25th son of Abdulaziz 'Ibn Saud', the founder of Saudi Arabia, Salman had a long path to the throne. In 1954, at the age of 19, he was made deputy governor of Riyadh Province, the home of the capital of Saudi Arabia. In 1963 he was promoted to governor, a position he held for 48 years, in which capacity he helped develop the capital into a thriving metropolis. He also developed skill in politics and diplomacy, skills he put to use as a member of the Sudairi Seven, a group of brother princes who amassed and wielded great power following the death of their father. As a reward for his loyalty and assistance to the group, Salman was placed in the line of succession, eventually being elevated to King at the age of 79 after the death of his brother, King Abdullah. As King, Salman reformed the government, streamlining the bureaucracy and placing his son as Crown Prince. He has been generous to his people, giving away over $32 billion, but cruel to his enemies, inflicting torture and death on those who criticize him or Islam. He has also been active in foreign affairs, intervening in the Yemeni civil war and providing support in the Syrian civil war to factions he finds favorable.
King Salman rules an Arabia that is strong in Faith and Oil.

Salman's unique ability means that his civilization will have abundant oil, which can be used to field a larger army or traded away for even greater wealth. With Arabia's Faith and Science bonuses, Salman will be well poisitioned to pursue a religious victory, either peacefully or with the sword.
Abdel Fattah el-Sisi
President of Egypt

Born and raised in Cairo, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi entered a long military career which culminated with his promotion to Field Marshal, the highest rank in the army. Sisi served on the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces during the Egyptian revolution that overthrew the military dictator Hosni Mubarak, later being installed as commander in chief. After the elected government of Mohammed Morsi's Muslim Brotherhood lost public support, Sisi staged a coup and ousted the government, installing a military council to serve in the interim between elections. Seeing his own popularity rising, Sisi resigned from the military and entered politics, winning election to become the President of Egypt. Sisi's administration has opposed radical Islam and attempted to promote a more tolerant society in the nation. Facing a severe economic situation, the Sisi government implemented severe changes, cutting government spending and allowing prices to rise. With the economy stabilizaing, Sisi has embarked on an ambitious infrastructure plan, including expanding the nation's road network and doubling the capacity of the Suez canal. On the foreign policy front, Sisi has strengthened his nation's relationship with other Arab countries and with Russia, but has seen the relationship with Turkey decline.
El-Sisi turns Egypt into a military powerhouse.

With bonus production from the military line of buildings and engineers with many charges, el-Sisi is well positioned to be a military builder. Strong late game units will give Egypt an extra boost towards finishing a Domination victory, at which el-Sisi will excel.
Justin Trudeau
Prime Minister of Canada

The son of Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, Justin was born in 1971 during his father's premiership and grew up under the shadow of the office. Trudeau spent many years in education, pursuing various degrees as well as teaching at the secondary level. In 2000 he first rose to prominence giving a well received speech at his father's funeral, finally entering politics in 2007 and winning a seat in Parliament in 2008. Following the Liberal party's worst ever electoral defeat in 2011, many party members clamored for Trudeau to take the reins and he was elected leader of the party in 2013. Trudeau campaigned hard and led his party to the greatest political comback in Canadian history in the 2015 elections, gaining 150 seats for a firm majority. As Prime Minister, Trudeau has governed in a decisively progressive manner, increasing deficit spending, advocating taxes on the rich, showing great concern for the rights of indigenous peoples, and championing many liberal causes.
Justin Trudeau is always looking to the future, and his civic bonus will help him advance faster than others.

Trudeau is an ideal match for the peaceful Canada, allowing it to race down the culture tree with a free inspiration every new era. Canada under him would do well to pursue either a Cultural or Diplomatic victory path.
Malcolm Turnbull
Prime Minister of Australia

The son of a hotel broker and a writer/actress, Malcolm Turnbull was ambitious from a young age, securing degrees in politics and law and becoming a Rhodes scholar. He threw himself into many careers, by turns working as a journalist, lawyer, investment manager, and CEO, along the way accumulating a large fortune. Turnbull first showed interest in politics in the 1980s, running unsuccessfully for election and then working as an executive of the Liberal party while still running his private practices. In the 1990s Turnbull also lead the Republican movement in their unsuccessful bid to convince the Australian people to vote to form a Republic. Finally elected to parliament in 2004, Turnbull quickly rose to prominence, becoming a Cabinet Minister and, when his party was defeated in 2007, becoming leader of the opposition in 2008. Representing the more moderate wing of the Liberal party, Turnbull clashed with the conservative wing and was forced out in favor of Tony Abbott, under who he would go on to serve as a shadow miniter in opposition and a Cabinet Minister when Abbott led his party back to power. In 2015 Abbott's declining popularity led Turnbull to successfully challenge him for leadership, becoming Prime Minister in his place. Turnbull would go on to lead his party to a narrow victory in the 2016 election. As Prime Minister, Turnbull has focused primarily on economic issues and reform.
Malcolm Turnbull helps Australia maximize the value of its trade and mining industries.

The trade bonuses Turnbull brings to Australia mean it is important to build trade units and good foreign relations as soon as possible to maximize profits. Combined with extra gold from mining, this allows Australia to more quickly amass a treasury when played optimally, a flexible bonus that can benefit any path to victory.
Enrique Peña Nieto
President of Mexico

Hailing from a middle class family in central Mexico, Enrique Pena Nieto had political ambitions from a young age. Earning degrees in law and business administration, Nieto worked briefly in the private sector before serving in various appointed political positions. In the early 2000s he entered electoral politics, first winning a position in his hometown before going on to win the governorship of the State of Mexico. Nieto entered office with the ambitious plan to deliver on 608 promises to the people, and while not all of them were achieved he did manage to make great strides in infrastructure and healthcare in the state. Following his term as governor he ran for president and won, bringing his party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), back to power after 12 years in the opposition. As president, Nieto was able to cooperate with several of the other political parties to implement various educational, financial, and telecommunications reforms. Nieto has also increased the size of the federal law enforcement divisions in Mexico to try to combat widespread violence perpetrated by the various drug cartels. Reform of the energy sector, to include ending the government oil monopoly, was also attempted without success due to political opposition. Nieto has also faced controversy, especially concerning the issue of media influence and the use of force in keeping the peace.
Enrique Peña Nieto enables Mexico to more quickly build up its industry and trade.

Faster district construction for industry and trade means Mexico should have an early edge in gold and production. Paired with Mexico's culture and tourism bonuses this makes it a solid civ that should be well positioned to pursue any victory conditions.
Joko Widodo
President of Indonesia

The son of a furniture maker, Joko Widodo studied forestry before following his father into the furniture business. Widodo's business was especially successful in foreign markets, and it was while selling goods abroad that he earned his nickname "Jokowi", by which he is popularly known. With the knowledge he gained in his business ventures, he decided to run for office as mayor of his hometown, Surakarta, with the goal of improving the city. Widodo's successful seven-year tenure as mayor improved his stature and popularity in the community, prompting him to run for Governor of Jakarta, a position he won. Widodo governed as a populist, listening to people's concerns, reforming the civil service, investing in infrastructure, and expanding social welfare programs. Following a term as governor, Widodo ran for the Presidency, which he narrowly won in the second round. As president, he has continued the populist policies that endeared him to the people, although financial difficulties have restrained his actions. He has also sought to protect Indonesia's sovereignty and to strengthen his nation's maritime capabilities.
Joko Widodo leads Indonesia to become a premier maritime civilization.
With bonuses to sea tiles, harbor construction, and naval experience, Indonesia under Jokowi will thrive as a coastal civilization. Unsuprisingly, this means it will excel on archipelago type maps.
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
President of Turkey

Born in Istandbul, Recep Tayyip Erdogan earned a business degree and played semi-pro association football (soccer) before entering politics. Erdogan joined an Islamist political party and won election as mayor of Istanbul, proving himself a talented and effective governor. His party was later proscribed for posing a threat to the secular character of Turkish government, and Erdogan himself was imprisoned after a public reading of a poem which included the line “our mosques are our barracks, the domes our helmets, the minarets our bayonets, and the faithful our soldiers”. Although the term of imprisonment was short, the punishment included a life-long ban from running for election. Undeterred, Erdogan started his own political party, which soon won parliamentary elections. The law banning him from electoral participation was lifted shortly before this victory, allowing him to ride the wave to power and become prime minister. During his administration, Erdogan made peace with the Kurds, shepherded his country successfully through economic turmoil, and invested in infrastructure, healthcare, and education. He also consolidated power, started transitioning Turkey from a secular state to a more Islamist one, cracked down on dissent, and watched as several of his political allies were exposed as corrupt. In 2014 he ran for and won the position of President of Turkey, a formerly symbolic position that he has since transformed into a powerful executive office. In 2016 a failed coup against Erdogan gave him an excuse to crack down on dissent, arresting or firing thousands of political enemies and censoring unfavorable press. In 2017 Erdogan pushed a constitutional revision to further consolidate power, the revision narrowly winning in an election marred by accusations of fraud. With his increasingly authoritarian tendencies and his penchant for Ottoman aesthetics, some have accused him of conspiring to become a modern day Sultan.
Erdoğan's strength is his capital, which grows stronger with each passing era.
Erdoğan's bonus is fairly well-rounded, and paired with Turkey's defensive bonuses this puts him in a good position to pursue any victory in relative security.
Mauricio Macri
President of Argentina

The son of a wealthy industrialist, Mauricio Macri earned a degree in civil engineering and followed his father's footsteps into business. He had a varied career in the private sector, working in construction, finance, and sports management. In 1991, at the age of 32, Macri was kidnapped by a group of officers of the Argentine Federal Police and held for 12 days until his father paid a multi-million dollar ransom for his release. This event sparked an interest in politics, and in 2003 he entered a political career himself, founding a new party and running for mayor of Beunos Aires. He lost, but gained much experience in the process, and after merging his party with another to form the Republican Proposal (PRO) he won a seat in the Argentine Chamber of Deputies in 2005. In 2007 Macri ran again for mayor of Buenos Aires, this time winning the office, in which he would serve two terms. Macri's time as mayor was generally successful, including a major overhaul of the city's public transportation and a reform of the police service. In 2015 Macri ran for the presidency of Argentina on a platform of reversing many of the policies of the Kirchners, a politcal dynasty that had held the presidency since 2003. Macri's opponent wanted to preserve the Kirchner legacy, and the close election went to a run-off in which Macri narrowly won. Macri's election was seen as the country taking a turn to the right, and he has embarked on an ambitious plan of economic reform to try to revitalize the economy and overcome the budget issues that have plagued the government for over a decade. He has also shifted foreign policy and sought to increase trade with many other nations.
Mauricio Macri brings economic reform to Argentina.

With an extra Economic policy slot and bonus to trade gold, Macri allows Argentina the flexibility to greater customize its economy and build up its treasury. These general purpose abilities pair well with Argentina's food bonuses, allowing the civilization to grow quickly.
Hassan Rouhani
President of Iran

Born Hassan Fereydun, he changed his name to Rouhani, meaning “Spiritual Cleric”, to reflect his religious devotion. Educated in religion at the Qom Seminary and in law at the University of Tehran, Rouhani joined the military and simultaneously advocated for revolution. After revolution came with the overthrow of the last Shah of Iran, Rouhani was elected to parliament. He served as a member of the Supreme Council of Defense and was also a deputy commander in the Iran-Iraq War. Winning the presidency in 2013, Rouhani is generally seen as more moderate than his predecessor, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, although Iran has continued its pursuit of a nuclear program as well as its support for the Assad dictatorship in Syria and various terrorist groups. The ultimate power in Iran, of course, rests not with the president but with the Supreme Leader Ali Khomeini, a Muslim cleric whose approval is required both to pass laws and to run for office in the nation, so Rouhani’s exact level of control over Iran’s policies is difficult to discern.
Hassan Rouhani can build coalitions of coreligious city states to strengthen Iran.

Iran under Rouhani is a very religious oriented civilization, and thus well positioned to pursue a Religious victory. Holy sites produce more faith, which can be used to proselytize City States, which makes it easier to suzerein them, which in turn provides a faith bonus. Faith can also be used to purchase faith and science buildings, allowing Iran to snowball if their religious ambitions are not checked.
Shahid Khaqan Abbasi
Prime Minister of Pakistan

The son of a prominent soldier and politician, Shahid Khaqan Abbasi was educated both in Pakistan and the United States and spent his early career working as an electrical engineer. When his father unexpectedly died in a military accident in 1988, the 30 year old Abbasi followed in his father's footsteps by entering politics and being elected to the National Assembly. Abbasi became a staunch ally of the powerful Pakistani politician Nawaz Sharif, and after Sharif was overthrown in a coup in 1999 Abbasi spent two years in jail for having assisted Sharif. When Sharif returned from exile in 2007, Abbasi once again ran for and won election to the National Assembly. In 2013 Abbasi joined the cabinet of the Sharif government as Minister of Petroleum and Natural Gas Resources. In 2017 Nawaz Sharif was barred from office by the Supreme Court of Pakistan for corruption uncovered in the Panama Papers case, forcing him to resign as Prime Minister. Sharif chose Abbasi to serve as a caretaker Prime Minister until Sharif's brother could join the National Assembly and be elected Prime Minister, but it was later decided that Abbasi should retain the Prime Minister position until the 2018 elections while Shehbaz Sharif instead strengthens the party's position ahead of the election. As Prime Minister, Abbasi appointed himself Minister of Energy and has focused on energy policy, infrastructure development, and bolstering foreign relations.
Abbasi benefits Pakistan in accumulating gold and increasing production.

From the beginning Abbasi brings extra gold to foreign trade routes, giving Pakistan a boost from the start. Later in the game his production bonus to Power Plants comes online, allowing Pakistan to finish strong.
Jacob Zuma
President of South Africa

Growing up in poverty following the early death of his father, Jacob Zuma received no formal schooling. He joined the African National Congress (ANC) at age 17 and began to agitate for the end of apartheid. After the ANC was banned in 1961, Zuma joined the local communist party and was later arrested and sentenced to 10 years in prison on Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela and other ANC members were also imprisoned. After release he left South Africa and worked for both the ANC and the communists in their underground activities, rising to leadership positions in both. When the ban on the ANC was rescinded in 1990, Zuma returned to South Africa, left the communist party, and worked to build the ANC in his home province. After the ANC won the government in 1994, Zuma was elected as party chair. Five years later he became Deputy President of South Africa, a position he held for six years. Following a brief hiatus, Zuma ran in the ANC primary for president and won decisively, guaranteeing his election to the highest office in a nation that has only elected the ANC since democratic elections were instituted. Despite many controversies, including government corruption and his promiscuous lifestyle in a country ravaged by AIDS, Zuma has managed to maintain power and win reelection in 2014. Zuma has declared that the ANC will rule South Africa until the end of time.
Jacob Zuma brings endurance and expertise to South Africa.

Under Jacob Zuma, South Africa suffers less war weariness, allowing it to better persist in times of crisis. He also brings a gold benefit from recruiting great people, which pairs well with South Africa's bonus for producing a variety of districts.
Muhammadu Buhari
President of Nigeria

Muhammadu Buhari started his career as a military man, graduating from the Nigerian Military Training College and receiving a commission as an officer in 1963. In 1966 he participated in the counter-coup that precipitated the Nigerian Civil War. Buhari fought on the side of the government and earned distinction, advancing his career. In 1975 he participated in another coup, afterward being rewarded with a governorship and later being appointed Commissioner for Petroleum and Natural Resources. Following a two year stint in this position, Buhari returned to the military and rose to the rank of general. In 1983 he led a coup, declaring himself the leader of the nation. Declaring a desire to fight corruption and vice in Nigeria, Buhari implemented a draconian regime with stiff penalties for all manner of offenses, including criticizing his regime. In 1985 he himself was overthrown in a coup, consigned to spend the next three years in prison. Buhari was later appointed to head the Petroleum Trust Fund of Nigeria, his success in this endeavor paving the way for his reentrance into politics. Buhari ran unsuccessfully for president several times, but in 2015 he moderated his views, promoted his image as a foe of corruption, and finally won the election. The transfer of power to him from the opposition party marked the first peaceful, democratic transition of power in Nigeria's history. As President, Buhari has attempted economic reforms, fought corruption, continued the fight against the Niger Delta militants in the south and the Boko Haram terrorist group in the north, and also had extended absences from the country to deal with health issues.
Muhammadu Buhari leads a civlization poised to grow, in one way or another.
Nigeria's bonuses position the civilization to grow tall, while Buhari's bonuses can help it grow wide. This gives Buhari's Nigeria great flexibility in how to approach the game.
Moon Jae-in
President of South Korea

The son of refugess from North Korea, Moon Jae-in studied to become a lawyer and was involved in political activism from a young age. After a stint in jail for protesting the dictatorship and a period of service in the military after being drafted, Moon finally finished his law degree and embarked on a career as a lawyer specializing in human rights. During his career he befriended a fellow human rights activist named Roh Moo-hyun, who would go on to become President of South Korea. Roh asked Moon to serve in his administration, which Moon gladly agreed to. Moon's competence serving the president greatly increased his status among the members of the Democratic United Party. After Roh retired from politics and later comitted suicide, Moon decided to enter politics in his own right. In the spring of 2012, Moon was elected to National Assembly, and in the fall of 2012 he ran unsuccessfully for the Presidency, losing to Park Geun-hye. Moon would go on to become the leader of the opposition, and after Park was impeached for corruption in 2017 he successfully ran for President. As president he has sought to move his country's policies to the left and has declared a desire for a peaceful reunification of the Koreas, a position that has been complicated by the increasing belligerence of his northern counterpart.
A peaceful South Korea will thrive under Moon Jae-in.

South Korea has bonuses to gold and science, while Moon Jae-in brings bonuses to culture when his civilization is at peace. This puts South Korea in a strong position to pursue any of the more peaceful victory types, but war will put Korea at a disadvantage. The diplomacy game will be very important for Moon Jae-in.
Kim Jong-un
Sumpreme Leader of North Korea

The son and grandson of the former communist dictators of North Korea, Kim Jong-un has followed in his predecessors’ footsteps. Living in lavish luxury while oppressing his people, many of who live in squalid poverty, Kim continues the now 67 year reign of authoritarianism in the north half of the divided Korea. The third son of Kim Jong-il, Jong-un was selected as the designated successor because he was thought of all his siblings to most resemble his father in temperament and will. He has consolidated his power by killing those considered threats to his position, including many family members. He has maintained a belligerant stance towards South Korea and the United States, continuing to develop nukes and missiles with which he threatens his enemies.
Kim Jong-un brings an aggressive stance to North Korea.

Under Kim Jong-un, North Korea is positioned to be a militaristic civilization, benefiting from surprise wars and able to easily amass troops. North Korea's troops are weaker in foreign lands, so if conquest is the order of the day Kim will have to bring many reinforcements. But given that Kim makes infantry at a double rate, this should not be a problem.
Benjamin Netanyahu
Prime Minister of Israel

Born in Tel Aviv, Benjamin Netanyahu served in the Israeli Defense Force during the Six Day War and the Yom Kippur War and also took part in several special forces missions, during one of which he was shot in the shoulder. Following his military service, Netanyahu earned a degree from MIT and worked as an economic consultant. He quit and founded an anti-terror institute following the death of his brother during a hostage rescue mission. Later he served as Israel’s ambassador to the United Nations, before entering politics as a member of the conservative Likud party. After achieving leadership of the party, Netanyahu was elected Prime Minister in 1996, becoming the youngest prime minister in Israeli history and the first born in Israel after the foundation of the modern Jewish state. A series of scandals and a failure to move the Israeli-Palestinian peace process forward led to his defeat in the following election, after which he reentered the private sector. In the early 2000s he returned to politics to serve as Finance Minister in Ariel Sharon’s administration once Likud had regained power. While in this position Netanyahu implemented a series of economic reforms that improved the nation’s economic situation. Disagreements within Likud led to a fracturing of the party, following which Netanyahu regained leadership of the party. He served as leader of the opposition for three years before once again being elected prime minister. A hardliner on foreign policy, Netanyahu has promoted a strong defense of the nation, which has helped him retain popularity despite weathering many storms. Netanyahu in 2015 became only the second prime minister in Israeli history to be elected to the position four times, and he is on his way to becoming the longest serving prime minister the nation has ever had.
Benjamin Netanyahu excels at espionage.

With Israel's strong defensive bonuses and Netanyahu's spy bonuses, this civiliztion is very capable of protecting itself and foiling the plans of its enemies. While none of its bonuses give it an edge to pursuing victory, it is more than capable of hampering the progress of its competitors.
Paolo Gentiloni
Prime Minister of Italy

A descendent of Italian nobility, Paolo Gentiloni studied political science in university and joined the work force as a journalist. Involved in politics from his youth, Gentiloni began the transition to a full time political career in 1993 when he served as the campaign spokesman for a candidate for the mayor of Rome, who upon winning appointed Gentiloni to the City Council. In 2001 he was elected to Parliament, and in 2007 he was a founding member of the Democratic Party, a merger of various center-left parties. In 2014 he was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs for the Renzi government, a position in which he distinguished himself. When Renzi resigned after failing to carry a referendum to amend the country's Constitution, Gentiloni was asked to form a new government and became Prime Minister. As Prime Minister, he has focused on the economy, labor reform, dealing with immigration, and electoral reform.
Paolo Gentiloni brings greater flexibility to Italy.
Converting both an economic and a military policy card slot into wildcard slots allows Italy greater flexibility in customizing its government. This makes it well suited for any playstyle.
Andrés Manuel López Obrador
President of Mexico

Andrés Manuel López Obrador, popularly known as "AMLO" from his initials, got his start as the son of a merchant family in southern Mexico. Not wanting to go into the family business, AMLO went to university in Mexico City, where he studied political science. AMLO started his political career by joining the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), the dominant party in Mexico, serving in several minor positions. In 1988 he and other disaffected leftists from the PRI left the party and formed a movement that would eventually become the Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD), which AMLO would lead from 1996 to 1999. In 2000 he was elected mayor of Mexico City, a position he held until 2005 during which time he oversaw a great deal of development in the city. After his success as mayor he ran for president in 2006 as the PRD candidate in a three-way race, narrowly losing in a contested election. In 2012 he ran again for president under the PRD banner, placing a distant second. After this election he had a falling out with the other leaders of his party, prompting him to leave and found a new party, the National Regeneration Movement (MORENA). As leader of MORENA he formed a broad political coalition and decisively won the presidential election of 2018. As president, he has sought to implement a broad series of reforms in an attempt to address the economic and security problems facing his nation.
AMLO brings reform, but not without cost.

AMLO's amenity bonus will allow Mexico to grow larger without being handicapped by unhappiness, but as a trade-off every city is a bit costlier to maintain. With bonuses to culture and building campuses, Mexico under AMLO is a very well-rounded civilization best equipped to pursue any of the more peaceful victory conditions.
Jair Bolsonaro
President of Brazil

One of six children from a middle class family in southeastern Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro started his career as a military man, serving in the Brazilian army for 15 years. His career took a turn when he published an article in a national magazine criticizing the government for their handling of the military, especially criticizing low pay. This article made him many enemies but also many supporters, so after a criminal case in which he was acquitted he left the military and took up politics. In 1988 he was elected to the city council in Rio de Janeiro, and in 1990 he was elected to the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house in the national legislature. Over the course of a 27 year career as a deputy he remained a polarizing figure, eventually becoming a champion for the political right wing despite a long history of controversial statements. In 2018, with Brazil's traditional political establishment discredited by a string of scandals, he siezed the opportunity to run for president. Running on a campaign of fighting corruption and crime while upholding traditional values, Bolsonaro gradually increased his support throughout the campaign. A significant event happened during the campaign when he suffered an assassination attempt, being stabbed while meeting with potential voters. After a month of recovery, he was back on the campaign trail, and Bolsonaro surprised many by winning the first round and then the runoff to become President of Brazil. As president he has generally moved policy in a more rightward direction.
Jair Bolsonaro is well positioned to exploit the wealth of the rainforest.

With Brazil's bonuses to building in rainforests and Bolsonaro's bonuses to harvesting and chopping, Brazil can fully exploit the rainforest tiles that other civilizations will probably avoid. In addition, Bolsonaro gets a bonus military policy, strengthening Brazil to defend its position.
Alberto Fernández
President of Argentina

Alberto Fernández was born and grew up in Buenos Aires, the capital of Argentina, and attended law school in the same city. After graduation he entered politics, serving in advisory and ministerial roles for many years. In 2000 he was elected to the Buenos Aires City Legislature, where he remained until 2003 when he was appointed Chief of Cabinet Ministers by President Néstor Kirchner. Fernandez served in this role for both Kirchner's tenure and part of his successor (and wife) Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner. After this, Fernandez served in minor roles for his party, until in 2019 Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner asked him to run for president, with her as vice president. They managed to win the election against incumbent Mauricio Macri, thereby returning their party to power. As president, Fernandez has embarked on a series of economic reforms, attempting to end the recession that Argentina is in.
Well governed cities will thrive under Alberto Fernández.

Argentina under Fernández is well-positioned to be a tall civilization, using the extra food from its improvements to grow and boosting the production and gold of its cities when a governor is present. As the governor bonus grows with governor promotions, it may benefit Fernández to have fewer, better promoted governors, and of course pursuing governor titles from civics and buildings is a must.
Boris Johnson
Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

Born in New York City to middle class British parents, Boris Johnson has shown ambition since an early age. Attending Eton College and Oxford University, he cultivated relationships with connected individuals and sought various student offices. After graduating from university he settled in London, where he entered the field of journalism. While working for The Daily Telegraph, Johnson developed a higher profile with his eccentric style and first began promoting the euroscepticism that would come to define his career. Johnson's first foray into politics was a failed run as the Conservative candidate in a safe Labour district in 1997, after which he returned to the news business. In 1999 he became the editor of The Spectator, a tenure marked by controversy, scandal, and an even greater profile on the public scene. In 2001 he ran for Parliament again, this time successfully. As an MP his popularity in Conservative circles increased, culminating in him being appointed shadow education secretary by David Cameron. In 2008 he ran for mayor of London and defeated the incumbent, going on to serve as mayor for two terms, during which the city hosted the Olympics. In 2015 he once again became a Member of Parliament, and in 2016 he became one of the leading voices for the Leave side of the Brexit debate. When Leave won, Conservative Prime Minister David Cameron, a Remain proponent, resigned, and was replaced by Theresa May, who appointed Johnson Foreign Secretary. In 2018 Johnson resigned this post over disagreements with May over Brexit implementation. In 2019 May resigned from the office of Prime Minister over the impasse in Parliament on Brexit implementation, and Johnson ran and won the leadership of the Conservative party, becoming Prime Minister. As Prime Minister, Johnson had no better luck then May with the impasse in Parliament, opting to call snap elections to resolve the issue. Johnson went on to lead his party to one of the largest victories in decades, securing a significant majority that will make legislating much easier for him in the future. As his marquee issue, he has promised to get Brexit done.
Boris Johnson can easily forge, abandon, and reforge alliances, giving him great diplomatic flexibility.

Johnson's England is a production and military powerhouse with great diplomatic flexibility. Johnson can build alliances faster, and others get over grievanes against him faster, meaning England under him can more easily realign their diplomatic position as circumstances change.
Giuseppe Conte
Prime Minister of Italy

Born and raised in southern Italy, Guiseppe Conte attended law school in Rome before embarking on a career as a law professor. In 2013, at the age of 49, he was elected by the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house of the Italian Parliament) to serve as a member of the Bureau of Administrative Justice. After the 2018 election left the Pariament split between the centrist Five Star Movement, right-wing League coalition, and left-wing Democratic Party, a deadlocked parliament finally consented to a compromise by elevating the independent Conte to Prime Minister of a Five Star Movement-League cabinet. Conte worked with this populist coalition to bring about reforms, but rising disagreements led to a dissolution of this government when the League partners voted for no confidence. However, before new elections could take place a new coalition formed between the Five Star Movement and the Democratic Party, which retained Conte as Prime Minister. Thus Conte became the first Prime Minister in Italian history to lead two separate governments of varying ideologies in the same legislative session. Conte has continued to work with his new government to enact reforms, with the result of his tenure so far being an array of left, right, and center reforms to policy.
Giuseppe Conte brings loyalty and good governance to his civilization.

Italy is oriented to be stronger at Cultural victories, provided it can build wonders, and with Conte at the helm it will not have to worry as much about loyalty issues. Conte also allows Italy to quickly build the Government Plaza and its buildings, allowing it to enjoy the benefits of government sooner than others.
Cyril Ramaphosa
President of South Africa

Born to a middle class family in Johannesburg, Cyril Ramaphosa attended university to study law, where he became involved in student groups resisting apartheid. After a stint in jail due to his activism, Ramaphosa became a law clerk and finished his degree by correspondence. He then joined the legal department of the Council of Unions of South Africa, where he was tasked with forming a miner's union that would become the National Union of Mineworkers. Ramaphosa would lead this union from its formation in 1982 until 1991, growing it susbstantially and using it to advocate for workers' rights and against apartheid. Achieving greater prominence in the anti-apartheid movement, Ramaphosa became a part of the committee that would negotiate the release of many anti-apartheid political prisoners, including Nelson Mandela. Following this, he was elected Secretary General of the African National Congress (ANC) in 1991, a role in which he played a key part in negotiating the end of apartheid. When free elections were held in 1994, Ramaphosa became a member of parliament. In 1997 he ran unsuccessfully for the presidency, after which he entered the private sector as an investor. His business dealings would prove successful, eventually making him one of the richest men in South Africa. In 2012 he returned to politics, being elected Deputy President of the ANC. Two years later he was appointed Deputy President of South Africa, and three years after that he was elected President of the ANC. When the president of the country, Jacob Zuma, resigned in 2018, Ramaphosa was elected unopposed to succeed him. Ramaphosa would lead his party to its sixth straight win in the 2019 elections. As President, he has focused on improving South Africa's economy, strengthening foreign relations, and promoting tourism. His economic reforms have included job programs and land reforms, controversially supporting the expropriation of land without compensation. He has also pledged to fight corruption in government.
Cyril Ramaphosa specializes in productivity and land redistribution.

South Africa under Cyril Ramaphosa will have a productivity edge from the start, although this is balanced by greater maintenance costs to cities. This paired with South Africa's bonuses to building a variety of districts in the same city means that Ramaphosa is well equipped to grow his civilization tall. However, should he decide to expand he can always redistribute some land from his neighbors using his unique farm culture bomb.
Imran Khan
Prime Minister of Pakistan

Hailing from an upper-middle class family in Lahore, Imran Khan was afforded a quality education that culminated in a degree from Oxford in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics. But his true love was cricket, and he was good at it, so after graduation he embarked on a career in the sport. In a career spanning nearly two decades he distinguished himself as one of the leading athletes in the sport, culminating with leading the Pakistan national team to victory in the 1992 Cricket World Cup. After retiring from cricket, Khan focused on philanthropy and politics. In 1996 he founded the Pakistan Movement for Justice (PTI) political party, with the aim of fighting corruption and establishing a welfare state. In 1999 he supported General Pervez Musharraf's coup, hoping he would clean up the corruption in government, but by 2007 he had become disillusioned with the new government and along with many other MPs resigned his position in Parliament. Khan was subsequently placed under house arrest for criticizing the government, but managed to escape. The Musharraf regime ended in 2008, allowing Khan to come out of hiding. Starting in 2011 Khan embarked on a speaking tour criticizing the government, in the process greatly increasing his political popularity. In 2013 he led his party to a modest success in the election, with PTI becoming the third largest party in parliament. Khan criticized the integrity of the elections, claiming vote rigging and leading protests against the government, but nothing was definitively proven. In the next elections in 2018 he led his party to victory, becoming Prime Miniser in the process. As Prime Minister he has focused on fighting corruption, reducing government waste, building a welfare state, ending terrorism in the country as peacefully as possible, and building stronger foreign relations with various nations.
Imran Khan has the flexibility to lead his civilization in any direction.

Having several policy slots converted into wildcard slots gives Imran Khan greater flexibility in tailoring the government of Pakistan. Paired with bonuses to faith and military, this makes Imran's Pakistan a robust civlization.
Scott Morrison
Prime Minister of Australia

Scott Morrison grew up in a middle class family in the suburbs of Sydney. He had a brief career as a TV child actor, and later attended the University of New South Wales to study economic geography. After graduation, he worked for the lobbying group Property Council of Australia for six years and then worked on the Australian Tourism Task Force for three. In 1998 he moved to New Zealand to serve as director of the Office of Tourism and Sport. In 2000 he returned to Australia to become the director of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, in which capacity he served until 2004, when he was appointed to director of Tourism Australia. In 2007 he was elected to parliament, quickly moving to the front benches and serving in the shadow cabinet. When the Liberal Party won the majority in the 2013 elections, Morrison was appointed Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, at which post he successfully reduced illegal immigration to Australia. In 2014 he was moved to Minister of Social Services, and in 2015 he was appointed Treasurer by the new PM Malcolm Turnbull. After several leadership spills prompted Turnbull to resign in 2018, Morrison was seen as a compromise candidate between the bickering factions of the party and was elected Prime Minister. In 2019 he led his party to a surprise victory in the elections, strengthening its position in parliament. As Prime Minister he has focused on trade and foreign relations, tax reform, and various other measures. In 2020 his popularity took a major hit after criticism that he had been slow to act to deal with the massive bushfires that swept a large portion of the country.
Scott Morrison is well positioned to exploit natural resources for Australia's benefit.

With accumulation bonuses to many strategic resources and gold bonuses to international trade routes, Morrison's Australia is in a good position to get rich by trading with others. As gold is a very flexible commodity, Australia will be free to pursue any victory condition it desires.
